comments.commentBody:
War on poverty? Needs to be fought continuously. They had an article today on the MSNBC website about colonel Robert Freniere who is trying to survive living in his van. I'm sure and at least hoping he will get an adequate position somewhere soon considering his enormous credentials and degrees.

When I was laid off from Boeing in 1969, even with a PhD degree I found the the professional job market was totally saturated and so I did the seemingly ridiculous move of taking a janitorial course and it did get me a job in this field unitl I could get back into a technical job position in 1972.

War on poverty won"t even be close to won until unemployed are given a workfare program to give them temporary job security until they can get a new position.

Mr. Kristof: Let's not choose between the old and the young. There is no need for the richest country the world has ever seen to choose between one or the other. We could aid the entire world, and make all of us here in the United States very comfortable, should we decide to pull back and not bomb small, defenseless countries, and make the off-shoring, tax-evading corporations pay up.

Our two compromised parties, representing over 300 million of us, have sold out to the Corporations, to the Military, and to their own lust for power. Our so-called representatives must be fired. They are bad actors in a tired soap opera, braying according to script, fortunate to not have been retired a decade ago. Now it's time for them to be relegated to appearances in cleanser commercials, talking loudly, their vacant eyes pleading that we send in $19.99, plus shipping and handling.

No, sir. The War on Poverty was a specific set of programs championed by LBJ in 1964. While the article notes correctly that increased Old Age Pensions and Medicare have made huge reductions in poverty among the elderly, the money stopped flowing to most of the rest of the programs as early as 1966. It's a lie to claim the battle was fought and lost--those battles we fought, we won. Those we didn't fight, indeed, have shown no improvement. Beautiful that you've twisted that into evidence against trying. Tell me, what, besides SS, Medicare and Medicaid (which is always being cut, little by little), still constitutes the War on Poverty? TANF is a shadow of its former self (thankfully, as it was a partial, though not complete, cause of what you mention--Moynihan's scissors and all). SNAP provides some food (not much, but enough to prevent some malnutrition and starvation), but not much money goes into each. So where is this war we're fighting, where the failures? The big money goes into SS and Medicare--successes. Show me money since the 90s that's been spent and failed on any large scale? I'll be waiting, sir.

Richard, you and others seem to suggest that the decay of the family and the resulting poverty stems from lazy, immoral people unwilling to work, expecting handouts from the rest of us to bail them out. But the reality is that the decay of the family is a direct result of the corporate/labor balance put in place by current policies. It now takes two wage earners or more to support a middle-class lifestyle. That flooded the market with new workers, depressed wages and added to the corporate/labor imbalance. The resulting stress on the family is the source of the decay. Now unemployment benefits, food stamps, and health care policies from Republicans are attempting to generate a free labor pool that along with additional tax policies would push that shift even further to corporate benefit. You suggest the war on poverty was lost and its time to try something new.  I agree with that, but the something new might be to actually do what we intended, instead of just giving more to the wealthy.
So, Richard, leaving aside the actual evidence about poverty amelioration that Mr. Kristof presents, what exactly is the "something different" you would have us try?

Drive through miles and miles of streets in cities like Baltimore and tell me with a straight face that we have made progress in the war on poverty. And knowing that these miles and miles of streets are virtual "father-free" zones, tell me with a straight fact that the war on poverty (essentially transfer payments to single mothers but not a dime to married couples) was not the direct cause of these "father-free" zones.

In fact, the war on poverty has been going on for 50 years. And poverty won, big time. But instead of surrendering and trying something different, we continue the same failed war, resulting in generation after generation of impoverished Americans.

Yes, their jail time should equal the amount of time they have been stealing from the government. They also need to make restitution. I bet however they will at best, receive a fine.
Any guess they will pay it without hiring a lawyer to file bankruptcy?

Anyone who can't connect Christie's appointee at the Port Authority, a friend from High School 30+ years ago, and his Deputy Chief of Staff, doesn't have a fully functional neural net. His fingerprints are all over BOTH appointees. The twelve bucks (toll back then on the bridge-now up to 15) stop with the tough guy who claimed he was working the traffic cones those days...

So let me get this straight. To punish a Democratic mayor for not endorsing him in a sure-thing election, made more so by expensively separating it from a special Senate contest, Christie has an aide block that mayor's constituents' kids on school buses, but he's savvy enough to leave no personal fingerprints. Of course, they deserve it because their parents vote Democratic anyway.

How many previous shenanigans has this team gotten away with? Politics at its pettiest and most ugly.

The most destructive and pernicious of modern knaves is the serial monogamist (SM). I don't care if the SM is male or female, queer or not - they leave behind shattered lives.

Humans are a feckless species. Nothing I or anyone else can say or do will ever change that. But we can do what we can to encourage folks to stay together, to enter into ties that bind, and not to break those ties except as a last resort, where you simply have no choice but to put distance between you and another person because they are a demonstrable danger to you, your kith and kin.

It's not a matter of personal happiness. It's a matter of accepting one's responsibilities for the effect of one's earlier choices. You made a mistake? Tough. Grow up. Man up. We made our bed - now we must sleep in it. We are responsible for our mistakes. We need to sort them out. We need to stick together through thick and thin, no matter how difficult that might seem at times. We are all parted soon enough. In the meantime, don't run away; don't abandon those whom you professed that you once loved. Stay together; support one another through the good times and the bad - especially the bad. That’s what a real man does, what a real woman does. Upright, righteous men and women don’t quit when the going gets tough. If that results in complex relationships that test the simplistic understanding of the meat and two veg brigade, then so be it.
Actually it's more the fact that they do see the museum as a "business" that is the problem.

I wanted TECTONIC PLATE at first.

ROUND number and beef ROUND (the best for pot roast, you know.)

CONTINENTAL DIVIDE was my first thought.

Good thing I hadn't cottoned onto the sliding trick, or I might have tried to make it fit.

In the end, I got some of the sliders but PRIMED for CUBED stymied me, and I think in this rare case solving online might have been easier than erasing and rewriting over and over.

I finally gave up -- duty calls! -- but it was a very clever and original concept.

Not to be confused with the "Teutonic Pate" of Colonel Klink:

http://www.aveleyman.com/ActorCredit.aspx?ActorID=9489

Count  me in the loved this column.  At first I thought this must be a rebus, but then tumbled to the device when I saw the "two" letter answer.  Thought of some kind of tectonic plate answer for the reveal, when san andreas fault popped in my head.  That made things fall into place nicely.
Yes, what does it say about "modern" architecture and in fact "modern art" in general. Its all disposable.

It's amazing that MOMA can squander money like this for all these years. As the leading institution in the collection and pursuit of high Architecture, they have been an utter failure themselves in creating Architecture for their own premises, not just architecturally significant structures but also apparently structures that do not even suit their functional requirements. The Pelli and now the Taniguchi expansions were much heralded in their day and are now banished, revised beyond recognition and will be virtually invisible. What does it say about MOMA's role in curating good Architecture when they cannot commission good and lasting Architecture for themselves and must paste over and obliterate their 'mistakes'? One wonders how long this Diller Scofidio version will last before it too will be deemed obsolete and a failure and must be replaced by the work of yet another Starchitect?

MOMA has redesigned itself too many times recently. Spend the money on art and the community. Stop being a real estate force in the neighborhood and remember your mission to bring art to the city of New York. Less architecture and more retrospectives and purchases of the art our city deserves to view. I'm a neighbor, one block away, and I urge you to truly act neighborly.
Lowry gets political cover for turning MOMA into a real estate company, and Diller gets a chit with MOMA, while tearing down her betters.  The city loses.  Nobody is surprised.
Maybe Diller Scofidio can provide bathroom sinks that don't splash water all over your clothes and the floor.
Not true. It's a scam to put investor money into a public service to allow it to charge any entry fee it wants.

This makes no sense to me.  So long as you are not up against resource limits, why would increased population limit wealth and real wages?  What is the postulated mechanism?  If there is too much inertia in the system (e.g., barriers to market entry), why would population limit growth?  If anything, it seems more population would mean more innovation, more specialization, etc., but I guess that assumes a well educated and integrated citizenry.  I don't know, it just seems that if there were an inverse relationship then real wages would have been steadily declining for the last 20,000 years.

"Criminal" is the key word here. Emergency vehicles were caught in the 4-hour delays as well - if anyone died as a result of this act of vicious, petty revenge, Christie & cronies should be charged with homicide. And everyone who suffered any injury or lost income or even lost a job as a result of this incident should be able to sue.

In fact, I don't think it's much of a stretch to characterize this incident - in which traffic in 2 states and the highest-traffic-volume bridge in the world was deliberately and maliciously jammed for several hours - as a terrorist act. As in, conspiracy to sabotage public infrastructure and interstate commerce.
I don't get it. Why would his aides do this and not tell him? How would they get political brownie points unless they tell him?
Also, Mr. Bennett, there is more self-deprecating humor in one verse of almost any Christine Lavin song than all the humor to be found in "Inside Llewyn Davis."

I wish I knew what Mr. Bennett finds so smart and hilarious about this film. Was it the funny scene with Llewyn's father? The park bench fight with "Jean"? Running over the cat?

I was terribly disappointed. With all the cultural and personal references, it is not possible to look at the film as a complete work of fiction, especially after the Coen Brothers' referencing Dave Van Ronk and the early 60s folk scene so much in their publicity. I felt like they were depicting Pottersville from "It's a Wonderful Life"! Why did they set this "fictional" film in this particular place and time?

When I worked for Mr. B. as his production manager, I suggested that he re-make The Angel Levine with Josh Mostel, Zero's son.  But before that I suggested he make a video of Zombie Jamboree as an antidote to Michael Jackson's Thriller.   I suppose that's why he told me to stick to production management.

"Siri, are you her?"
-alan

"Joaquin? Is that you?"
-Siri
I am keeping my fingers crossed!

The ending, where Cephus Parker, the shop owner from Saratoga Springs, NY, pulls into the plantation with Northup's "free papers," and is able to extricate the enslaved man with the help of the friendly local sheriff, doesn't pass the smell test. I picked up a copy today and it's obviously a completely different person, not Parker, who shows up at the plantation.

In reality, Northup was feed when his African American family contacted the Governor of New York (Washington Hunt) and set in motion a process that reached the highest levels of government and included: former Louisiana Senator Pierre Soulé, Supreme Court Justice Samuel Nelson, and Charles M. Conrad, U.S. Secretary of War.

Even so, Northup and the official state agent appointed by Gov. Hunt to rescue him, had some problems in S.C. because Solomon was not registered as the man's servant.

I don't condone any insults Mr. McCoy may have spoken, however, it's just possible that his radar detector is in fine working order concerning that ending.

Last paragraph:

http://docsouth.unc.edu/fpn/northup/summary.html
Re the description of Jared Leto: did Cara Buckley not learn anything from last month's Megyn Kelly/FOX News kerfuffle over the ethnicities of Saint Nick and Jesus? They are not European.

What a great interview and a great representative of the Costume Designers Guild.  Thank you for this feature and good luck with the Academy this year.  Your work is inspiring across the board, Michael.  The costumes were such an entertaining layer of the film.

1) Bravo Harry Belafonte!

2) Armond White has denied he heckled McQueen
